_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES

The Service Cold Storage, Stevens Point facility, refrigeration system uses pure anhydrous ammonia (a commonly used refrigerant for industrial systems) as the refrigerant. Given the quantity handled, anhydrous ammonia is considered a hazardous substance by EPA. Many of the properties that make ammonia valuable as a refrigerant also requires that precautions and procedures be in place to protect employee and public health and safety during a chemical emergency. It is the policy of Service Cold Storage to be in compliance with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. 



Safety at our facility is inherent in the manner in which anhydrous ammonia is handled. While the design of the facility incorporates a multitude of safety devices, safe handling procedures combined with appropriate training of our personnel, are key aspects to maintaining safety at our facility.



We have a written Process Safety Management (PSM) and an Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordinating with outside parties. This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events. 



2. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Service Cold Storage, Stevens Point facility, is a refrigerated warehouse.  Access to the facility is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel, and contractors.  The regulated substance at this facility is anhydrous ammonia, and the maximum intended inventory of this covered process chemical is 16,800 pounds. 



3.  DESCRIPTION OF THE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Service Cold Storage complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. The design and construction of this facility was in accordance with published standards.



Service Cold Storage's written PSM plan incorporates many policies and proce

dures to ensure safe operation and maintenance of this facility. Plan elements essential to safe operation of the refrigeration systems include employee participation, Process Safety Information (PSI), Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Standard Operating Procedures (SOP), training, contractor safety, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR), mechanical integrity, Management of Change (MOC), hot-work permits, incident investigation, emergency response and planning, and compliance audits. This plan will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary.



Training is provided to ensure that each employee involved in operating a process has been trained in an overview of the process, the operating procedures, and safety considerations. This training uses guidelines developed by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) and Refrigeration Engineers Technology Association (RETA). Only qualified maintenance personnel operate and interact with the refrigeration system. This minimizes the chances of inadvertent error in operation that could lead to a release of ammonia. Startup, shutdown, and any system adjustments are handled by these qualified persons. 



4.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENTAL RELEASE HISTORY



The facility has not had a reportable release of anhydrous ammonia within the last five years.  The facility opened on 6 June 2014.



5.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM DESCRIPTION



Service Cold Storage has a written Emergency Action Plan developed to ensure that precautions and procedures are in place to protect employee and public health and safety during a chemical emergency. The Emergency Action Plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordinating with outside parties. This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events. 



The approach in the development of this plan has been to identify the ammonia emergencies most likely to occur at the Service Cold Storage facility and establish precautions and procedure

s to protect life, safety and health during an emergency. The refrigeration process has back-up prevention systems to keep processing malfunctions from becoming ammonia release emergencies. If an emergency does occur, the following response personnel, facilities, and equipment are in place:



Emergency Alarm and Communication System

Evacuation Routes, and Assembly Points

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)



A copy of the site's emergency plans has been sent to the Portage County LEPC and the local Fire Department tours the facility.



All Service Cold Storage personnel will be trained to fulfill their designated responsibilities in an emergency. 



This plan will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary.



6.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Upgrades or extensive maintenance work performed in the future will be in compliance with those standards applicable at that time and will also be evaluated through the Management of Change (MOC) element as required by PSM standards. In addition, all of the recommendations from the initial PHA will be addressed in a timely manner which will improve the safety and practice of the Service Cold Storage facility.
